metadata.case_name: Secretary, Peoples Publishing House Ltd. v. State of Bombay
metadata.case_number: Appeal under Art. 132(1) from High Court Case No. IX of 1950

facts.text: Petitioner/appellant was Secretary of Peoples Publishing House Ltd., incorporated under Indian Companies Act, registered office at 190-B, Khetwadi Main Road, Bombay.
In September 1949, pamphlet entitled 'Railway Mazdooron ke khilaf Nai Zazish' alleged to have been published in Bombay by petitioner as secretary of the company.
Pamphlet claimed by petitioner to be a book under s.1 Press and Registration of Books Act 1867, provisions complied with.
Bombay Government viewed pamphlet as news sheet under s.2(6) Indian Press Emergency Powers Act 1931, published without authority u/s 15(1), offence u/s 18(1).
Prosecution started against petitioner in Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, registered as Case No. 1102/P of 1949.
Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.
On March 3, 1950, petitioner filed written statement claiming s.2(6), 15, 18 of 1931 Act ultra vires Art 19(1)(a) r/w Art 13, sought stay till High Court decides.
On March 7, 1950, petition filed in Bombay High Court u/ Art 228 to send record, declare ss.15,18 r/w 2(6),2(10) ultra vires Art 19(1)(a), order acquittal.
On March 23, 1950, Chief Presidency Magistrate framed charge u/s 18 of 1931 Act.
Art 228 petition heard on April 12, 1950 by Chagla C.J., Bavdekar and Shah JJ., dismissed, holding pending proceedings not affected even if inconsistent.
High Court granted certificate u/ Art 132(1) for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss.15(1) and 18(1) r/w ss.2(6) and 2(10) of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act 1931 inconsistent with Art 19(1)(a) r/w clause (2)?
Assuming inconsistency, whether proceedings commenced u/s 18(1) before commencement of Constitution can nevertheless be proceeded with?

petitioner_arguments.text: 1931 Act repressive law by alien government to stifle press liberty; Constitution guarantees fundamental rights u/ Art 19(1)(a); Art 13(1) declares inconsistent laws void as if never existed; pending prosecutions must fall as void law cannot be used post Jan 26, 1950.
Not contending ab initio voidness reopening closed transactions, but from Jan 26, 1950, inconsistent laws cannot be looked at for framing charge or punishing.
Void under Art 13 like repeal/expiry without saving clause; pending proceedings terminate; ss.2(6),15,18 void.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Press Emergency Powers Act ss.2(6),15,18; common law rules on repeal/expiry; Maxwell on Statutes

respondent_arguments.text: Art 13(1) prospective, not retrospective; declares existing laws void only to extent of inconsistency for future; past liabilities/pending proceedings survive.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art 13(1), 372(2); General Clauses Act s.6; no retrospective operation

respondent_arguments.text: Art 13(1) analogous to repeal, attracts s.6 General Clauses Act via Art 367; pending proceedings saved.
Fundamental rights operative only from Jan 26, 1950; pre-Constitution act punishable under then-existing law.

court_reasoning.text: Spirit from language; Art 13(1) prospective, not retrospective/ab initio; void only to extent of inconsistency for future exercise of fundamental rights; past transactions/pending proceedings survive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Existing laws void only prospectively; no retrospective effect.

court_reasoning.text: Fundamental rights created by Constitution from Jan 26, 1950; inconsistency arises only then; Art 13(1) not obliterating past operation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No fundamental right not to be prosecuted for pre-Constitution offence.

court_reasoning.text: Like Presidential repeal u/ Art 372(2) attracting General Clauses s.6; preservation of pending proceedings not foreign to Constitution. (Das J. majority)
Void means nugatory/ineffectual; no saving clause needed as prospective; pending proceedings cannot continue post-Constitution if inconsistent. (Fazl Ali J. dissent)
court_reasoning.key_observation: Law ceases to be effectual; prosecutions fall.

court_reasoning.text: Art 13(1) prospective; no retrospective; pending saved without needing General Clauses s.6; past acts punishable. (Mahajan J. concurrence)

holdings.text: Art 13(1) prospective; proceedings under inconsistent pre-Constitution laws pending on Jan 26, 1950, can continue.

precedents_cited.relevance: Effect of repeal: obliterates as if never passed, except past/closed; pending terminate without saving.
Repeal: considered except as to past/closed transactions as if never existed.

precedents_cited.case_name: J.K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co. v. King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Expiry of temporary Act: pending prosecutions terminate unless saved.
Repeal during proceedings: no further effect, though past done not undone.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wall v. Chesapeake Ohio Ry. Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Repeal: pending suits stop; appellate court applies law at decision time.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Press (Emergency Powers) Act, 1931
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined news-sheet; required authority for publication; punishable offence; claimed ultra vires.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Voidness of inconsistent laws; freedom of speech; appeal certificate; transfer case; savings for temporary laws; interpretation; adaptation.

statutes_cited.name: Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioner claimed pamphlet as book, complied.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Effect of repeal: saves pending proceedings.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; proceedings under Indian Press Emergency Powers Act 1931 pending before Constitution commencement can continue notwithstanding potential inconsistency with Art 19(1)(a) via Art 13(1).

key_quotes.text: "All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Art 13(1) text; central to prospective interpretation.

key_quotes.text: Article 13(1) can have no retrospective effect but is wholly prospective in its operation.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The effect of repealing a statute is to obliterate it as completely from the records of Parliament as if it had never been passed...
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Relied on for arguing pending terminate.

key_quotes.text: null and void ineffectual nugatory having no legal force or binding effect unable in law to support the purpose for which it was intended.
key_quotes.speaker: court
